object.content:
I finally got to see The Life of Pi in the theater this weekend - and it's well worth seeing on the big screen, because the cinematography is simply gorgeous. (I didn't see the 3D, because the glasses tend to give me a headache, and I didn't want that to affect my appreciation of the story.)

I am happy to say that the film was incredibly faithful to the book. There were a lot of things about the way the story is told in the book that I thought might be abandoned, because there are things you'll accept in prose that just won't work in film. But is precisely those things that make the book so precious to me. Ang Le managed to conquer those hazards admirably, so I am content. In fact, I feel I understand what it's about even more clearly.

It's hard to explain why this story touches me so deeply without risking spoiling it for people who haven't read or seen it, but I'm planning to blog more about it later. I'll just say this for now: this is not a story about a boy and a tiger in a boat, or about survival against impossible odds. It's about stories, and the liminal space between rationality and faith.
